newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Flood damage may lower Slovak harvest by one-third.
newsitem.headline: Flood damage may lower Slovak harvest by one-third.

text.p: As much as one-third of Slovakia's 1997 grain harvest may be lost as a result of heavy rain and flooding, the economic daily Hospodarske Noviny said on Tuesday.
The paper, quoting Agriculture Minister Peter Baco, said about a third of the grain crop had been flattened by the rain and would be difficult to harvest.
"Exact information (on the extent of the damage) and damage estimates will only be available in a few days time," Baca said.
Ministry officicals were not immediately available for comment.
Last week the Slovak Statistical Bureau (SUSR) estimated the 1997 grain harvest at up to 3.12 million tonnes, an increase of 19.1 percent over 1996.
The rapeseed harvest has been estimated at between 199,000 and 208,000 tonnes, an increase of 42.6 percent over 1996, SUSR said.
Rain and floods have delayed harvesting in southern Slovakia, the country's grain belt, the official news agency TASR reported quoting regional agricultural authorities.
Only some 1,500 hectares, or 0.81 percent out of 190,017 hectares of sown grain has so far been harvested in the southern region, TASR said.
In addition to a delay in the harvest, the flooding has also resulted in below-average grain yields, TASR said.
According to preliminary figures winter wheat yields will fall to 4.42 tonnes per hectare from an earlier estimate of 4.9 tonnes.
But winter barley yields are expected to increase to 4.42 tonnes per hectare from an estimated 4.28 tonnes, the agency added. --Peter Javurek, Bratislava Newsroom, 421-7-521 8402
